title: Sri Lanka stocks fall to near six-month low on margin calls, economic concerns
body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s stock index plunged nearly 5 percent on Tuesday (29) as margin calls and selling pressure intensified amid economic concerns after a steep fall in the rupee continued to dent investor sentiments, brokers said.
The main All Share Price Index (ASPI) fell 4.88 percent or 494.74 points to close at 9,647.55, its lowest close since October 06, 2021.
“Following a panic selling by retailers, index displayed a continuous decline and was dragged down below the 10,000 level,” First Capital said in its market note.
“Towards the end, the market was halted for 30 minutes since S&P SL20 index dropped over 5.0% from the previous close as pressure from margin providers got escalated.”
S&P SL20 of the most liquid stocks ended 2.9 percent or 105.46 points lower to 3,533.66 points.
Analysts had cautioned that if the market falls below 10,000 mark there would be a spiral effect, creating a downward trend.

Analysts said many investors are still concerned over how the government is going to face the mounting debt as they are not still confident if it would really go to the IMF or drag the decision of seeking IMF help.
The day’s turnover was 2.7 billion rupees, nearly half of this year’s average daily turnover of 5.11 billion rupees.

Analysts said investors are trying to shift their savings to hedge against the rupee fall and inflation, which is at a record high and more than 5 percent higher than one-year Treasury bill yield. Brokers said investors opt for stocks to hedge against inflation.
Sri Lanka’s rupee has fallen over 50 percent since it was allowed flexibility on March 07.
All commodity prices in Sri Lanka have been on the rise due to the currency fall.
Rising oil prices, policy rate hikes, a slowing economy, and shortage of dollars, fuel, and cooking gas along with extended power cuts continues to dampen the sentiment.

The market has lost 16.6 percent so far in March after falling 11 percent in the previous month. Overall the market has lost 21 percent so far this year after being one of the world’s best stock markets with an 80 percent return last year.
Foreign investors bucked the trend and bought a net 147.6 million rupees worth of shares. However, the market has witnessed a total foreign outflow of 2 billion rupees so far this year.
LOLC Holdings, Browns Investment and Expolanka dragged the index down on Tuesday.

Shares in LOLC Holdings fell 11.2 percent to close at 698.50 rupees a share, Browns Investment fell 11 percent to close at 8.90 rupees a share while Expolanka slipped 4.7 percent to close at 245.25 rupees a share. (Colombo/March29/2022)
